title: London terror attacker was once Kent schoolboy called Adrian Elms
text:
Khalid Masood was once a kEnt schoolboy called Adrian Elms, it has been claimed (Picture: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) The London terror attacker Khalid Masood was once a Kent schoolboy named as Adrian Elms before his religious conversion, it has been claimed. 
The 52-year-old who killed four innocent people and injured near 40 in the attack on Parliament yesterday has a string of criminal convictions including stabbing a man in the nose, the Mail Online reports.
Man, 75, injured in London terror attack dies in hospital The former English teacher, who was a keen bodybuilder, grew up in Kent before moving to Birmingham and is believed to have been known by a number of aliases.
He was born to a single mother and grew up in the seaside town of Rye in East Sussex.
His latest offence came in 2003, when he stabbed a 22-year-old man in the face outside a nursing home in Eastbourne.
Masood had a string of criminal convictions (Picture: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) He was later charged with GBH, wounding with intent and possession of an offensive weapon.
According to reports, he was jailed in 2003, which is where he may have been radicalised.
Born on Christmas Day in 1964, he was described by a source to Sky News as a ‘very religious, well spoken man’.
Police said yesterday they believed the former English teacher was inspired by international terrorism and ISIS have since claimed responsibility.
The attacker was shot dead by officers on the scene (Picture: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) However, there has been no firm evidence connecting the attacker and the terror group.
Masood drove along Westminster Bridge yesterday afternoon killing a mother-of-two and a man in his mid-50s and injuring another 29 people, some of them critically.
London terror attack was 'difficult to prevent but easy to organise' He then got out of the vehicle and ran round the corner to get into the grounds of the Palace of Westminster.
There he stabbed police officer Keith Palmer to death before being gunned down.
Theresa May told MPs he was a ‘peripheral’ figure, adding: ‘He was not part of the current intelligence picture.’
UPC Keith Palmer was stabbed in the attack (Picture: Metropolitan Police/PA Wire) Kurt Cochran was visiting the UK from America (Picture: Facebook) Aysha Frade was killed while walking to collect her children from school (Picture; Facebook) Describing the terrorist, Mrs May said: ‘What I can confirm is that the man was British-born and that some years ago he was once investigated by MI5 in relation to concerns about violent extremism. He was a peripheral figure.
‘The case is historic. He was not part of the current intelligence picture. There was no prior intelligence of his intent or of the plot.’
